text: (soft piano music)
- We're at this wonderful facility
at the Met Office in Exeter, built in 2003

but the history of the Met
Office goes much further back.
- Yeah, right back to 1859
and the back of the Royal Charter Storm
which killed 400 people.
And then through to 1944

when Stagg, the meteorologist
allowed the window

for the D-Day landing
to take place and then

through today where really
adding value for the UK economy.
- How is that informing your mission

and your vision for the support
citizens and businesses?

- Our mission is really not
much different to when created.

It really is about helping
people to make decisions
to keep them safe and to thrive.

What has changed is the
environments, the social conscience
we bring, and therefore it really is

about helping citizens,
government, and industry thrive
in the 21st century.

- I hear we're actually
doing some work together
in space weather.
What's that about?

- We have started to move
our space weather services
and products onto AWS Cloud.
That's really given us increased level
of performance, reliability

and allowing our teams to
disseminate that information
to customers much more quickly.
- How has the use

of technology helped to
support your customers?

- We are constantly moving
more products and services

into the AWS Cloud, and
that might be the app

which allows you to work
out whether you wanna to
have a barbecue next Sunday,

fishermen in the North
Sea using our app to work
out the latest weather conditions.

And we had some big
storms in February, 2022

where we had 2.3 million
users using our app
in that particularly week.
We're also using AWS

for our national severe
weather warning service.

And actually by not having it
within our own data services
and on the cloud,
it reduces the time to produce

the national severe
weather warning by 80%.
It literally is a click of a button.

- What are the kind of
key phases and approaches
to the use of data in the MET Office?
- So we've got so much data
and it's about getting that into a format.

We are using AWS Cloud to
bring in our observations data
and actually the ability

of being able to create
that data and put it
into the cloud to store it,
to play with it,
to experiment.
It is really important for our scientists

for our meteorologists,
and for our customers.

We can't do that without
machine learning automation.

- We hear a lot about
the digital skills gap.

Is that something that
concerns the Met Office?

- It's a real concern for
the Met Office executive
on the board, even pre-pandemic.
It's really important we work with schools

and get our resources
and material out there to

attract future generations
into the Met Office.
And then working with the likes of AWS

around how you can help
us track the right skills
to the Met Office in the future

and really look forward down
to having a conversation

about the AWS Academy and
education to workforce scheme.

- As you think about the
future and your relationship
with AWS, where do you see that going?
- We're definitely moving

more of our products
and services to cloud.

Beyond that customer
centricity, we share a lot
of values and our core mission

about having global
impact is very similar.
And then finally, actually

it's really good to work
with a trusted partner

who's got a strong
environmental credentials.
It's really inspiring to hear you want to

power all your operations
by renewable energy by 2025.
